FRIDAY, APRIL 7, 1905..

div.head: THE RISING SUN.
div.p: Now that the war in the East is running to its close, we are finding time to think about it. The victories of Japan, and the successes of this nation in peace and war, have disturbed our conception of things. We have to revise our outlook on the world, and readjust our angle of vision. Ideas which have been traditional for centuries have been rudely shaken. It is long indeed since the nations of the Teutonic and Celtio and Latin stocks have had even to admit the possibility of rivalry on this planet. We were free to quarrel among ourselves, secure in the conviction that the "inferior races" could play no more than the part of interested spectators. That they should take a hand in the game seemed almost as unnatural as it must have been to Gulliver when he reached a land where the men drew the carriages and the horses sat inside.

For centuries the East has been falling back before the West. Civilisation, in our haughty conception, has had a special and limited meaning, Even Stubbs, that catholic and comprehensive historian, thought that the only peoples whose annals were really worth studying, were those corthern races which had grafted the ethics of Christianity on the culture of Greece and the jurisprudence of Rome. That, until the other day, was the orthodox theory of human progress. Liberty, law, education, discovery, all the things of which we are proud, are supposed to trace back ultimately to the union above mentioned. Without them there could be no true civilisa-: tion; only a certain mechanical proficiency in material arts, like the decorative work of the Arabs, or some mere fighting instinct, such as that of the Turks or the Mongols. In war or peace the East could never be more than second best, childish, barbario.

But the events of the past fourteen months give us pause, Here we have to do with a people which has not and never has been, Christianised, Romanised, or Hellenised, and which, apparently, has in its veins no single drop of the white man's blood. And this people has only to set itself to the business to show that in most of the things which we regard as the peculiar products of our European civilisation, it is equal to the best of us. We have grown up in the belief that in this rather vital. matter of warfare no Asiatic or Oriental race could really hold its own with Europeans. We know now that this axiom requires to be modified. But the Japanese have clearly other qualities besides those of the soldier. Does civilisation mean a high intellectual culture, the deepest feeling for art and beauty, the gilt of-organisation, the love of order, decorum, discipline, and justice? All these qualities and aptitudes the Japanese seem to possess, It was startling for our critics to find that these distant islands had mastered the secrets of colour and workmanship. The show of Japanese objects at the first French Exhibition left upon our artists an impression which is not likely to be effaced. If there had been no Japan there would have been no Whistler.

It is, however, on the ethical side that this revelation from the Far East is most striking. We of Europe and America have always been able to comtort ourselves with the. thought that morality, in its highest sense, was our own especial prerogative. It is the white man's privilege. Yet we are confronted with a non- Christian Eastern people, which is not only brave, but orderly, temperate, generous and humane; which is said to have carried selfcontrol and self-restraint to a pitch beyond the reckoning of our philosophers and divines; and has developed the loftiest code of honor, patriotism, and devotion to duty. We cherish the memory of a single hero, here and there, like that Switzer of Sempach, who gathered the points of the hostile spears into his breast to make an opening for his comrades. But whole battalions of the common men of Nippon act like that. In the trenches before Port Arthur a Japanese colonel calmly gave the command: "The honorable front rank will throw itself on the enemy's bayonets." The honorable front rank instantly obeyed. They flung themselves upon the spikes, and made a causeway with their writhing bodies, over which their companions marched. A regiment of Arnolds von Winkelried! And those who thus outrival the self-immolation of the warrior ants and the Ghazis are not soulless or mindless machines, but men of intelligence and sensibility. There must be a good many persons who are asking themselves whether the ethical system which has produced such extraordinary results is not worth study. The Russians believe in their faith as no other Christian people do, unless it be the Spaniards. And if we look at the recent history of Russia and Spain on the one side, and then at Japan on the other, the result is a little disturbing. We remember that at the beginning of the New Era the Mikado sent a commission of statesmen to study the institutions of Europe and America. The commissioners recommended an adaptation of the British Navy, Prussian finance, American education, and so on; but they reported that no reproduction of our religious or ethical systems was worth considering. In these matters Japan had nothing to learn from the West. Perhaps she may have something to teach..

div.head: EGYPTIAN MARKETS.
div.p: In another column of to-day's issue we publish the report of the directors of the Egyptian Markets, Limited, for the past year. Although the results of the year's trading may be considered somewhat disappointing, owing to the fact that all the cattle markets have been closed during the year to horned cattle, still we think the shareholders will appreciate, the efforts of their directors under such trying circumstances. Not only have their efforts to decrease working expenses been so far successful, butthey have also given up over £1,500 of their fees, thus making a total revenue for the year of £18,580. Further, the shareholders are to be congratulated on the extension of the concession for a further term of ten years. All things considered, the Egyptian Markets should now have weathered the storm, and be entering on a period of prosperity.
THE WAR.
RUSSIAN ATTACK REPULSED.
TOKIO, April 6.

Oyama reports that the Japanese have now advanced 40 miles along the Tieling-Kirin road. Three Russian columns of all arms attacked Chincheafun, to the west of the railway, during the afternoon of the 3rd inst. They approached within 400 metres. The Russians were repulsed in the evening. Their losses are estimated at 200. The Japanese lost (Router)
27 men.

div.head: AUSTRIAN ATTACHE FOUND SAFE
div.p: VIENNA, April 6.
The Austrian Attaché, Count Scheptzizky, for whom the Japanese were vainly seeking, has been found safe with General Rannenkampf's army. (Reuter.)

div.head: PLOT AGAINST THE TSAR.
div.p: MAN ARRESTED AT TSARSKOE SELO.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 6.1

It is reported here that a man, disguised as a colonel of Cossacks, entered the Palace at Tsarskoe Selo on Monday during the reception of officers. He was arrested. Two small bombs were found on him. (Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIAN PROCURATOR RESIGNS.
div.p: PATRIARCH TO BE ELECTED.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 5.

M. Pobiedonostzeff, the reactionary Procurator of the Holy Synod, resigns. The Patriarch will be elected as head of the Church. This step is the outcome of the new reforming tendencies in the Church. (Reuter.)

div.head: GERMANY AND MOROCCO.
div.p: THE "OPEN DOOR."
BERLIN, April 6. It is understood in well-informed circles. that Germany desires to settle the Morocco question by means of an international confe-
rence.
(Reuter.)
WASHINGTON, April 6.

The German Ambassador here called at the War Department, and left a memorandum with Mr, Taft stating that Germany will stand -out for the "open door" in Morocco as well as in the Far East, and for the preservation of the "status quo" and the sateguarding of the commercial relations of all nations. France was not mentioned in the memoraudum. The latter has been communicated to President Roosevelt. (Reuter)
BERLIN, April 6.
The German Minister at Tangier has been recalled. Doctor Rosen, the negociator of the recent treaty with Abyssinis, has been appointed his successor. (Reuter.)

div.head: KAISER AT NAPLES.
div.p: TOAST WITH KING VICTOR.
Roxx, April 6.

King Emmanuel paid a visit and lunched with the Emperor William on board the "Hobenzollern." Signor Tittoni and the Ger man Ambassador were present. The Kaiser is returning the visit on board an Italian warship.
(Heuter.)
NAPLES, April 6. King Victor Emmanuel and Emperor William toasted their friendship and the cause of peace based on the alliance. (Havas.)

div.head: MACEDONIAN OUTRAGES.
div.p: BRITISH PROTEST TO THE PORTE.

CONSTANTINOPLE, April 6. Sir N. R. O'Conor, the British Ambassador here, has seriously protested to the Porte against the ontrages committed by soldiers and Mussulman villagers in Macedonia upon Bulgarians. He also protests against the destruction of the village of Zervi, where 34 corpses were found amongst the ruins. (Reuter.)
GOVERNMENT DEFEAT AT
BRIGHTON.
OPPOSITION'S WILDEST ENTHUSIASM.
LONDON, April 6.

In the bye-election at Brighton, Mr. Villiers, Liberal, obtained 8,209 votes against 7,392 votes polled by Mr. Loder, Conservative. The result was received in the House of Commons with the wildest enthusiasm on the part of the Opposition. At the conclusion of the sitting, Mr. Lloyd-George and others demanded a dissolation, declaring that the election was an expression of the country's disgust with the Government. Mr. Balfour's absence was criti- (Reuter.)
cised.

div.head: THE INDIAN EARTHQUAKE.
div.p: BOMBAY, April 6.
The mortality at Lahore is estimated between 50 and 100, all natives, although almost every house was damaged. (Bouter)

div.head: THE KING IN FRANCE.
div.p: REAFFIRMATION OF THE ENTENTE
PARIS, April 6. His Majesty the King of England has start ed for Marseilles.

President Loubet met King Edward's train at Pierrefitte and accompanied his Majesty here. They greeted each other quite in an informal manner like two personal friends. Although the meeting was mooted prior to the Emperor William's visit to Tangier, it is regarded everywhere as an unmistakeable reaffirmation of the "entente," with special reference to Germany's interposition in Morocco.
(Reuter.)
PARIS, April 6.
M. Loubet got into the train at Pierrefitte station and accompanied King Edward as far as Paris. The interview was very cordial.
The police discovered some military uniforms and rifles. It is believed there is a plot. (Havas.)
THE BRINDISI MAIL will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 8.30 am. on Sunday.
QUARANTINE restrictions, as against plague, are now applied in Egyptian ports to arrivals from Newcastle (New South Wales).

SUEZ CANAL-9 vessels passed through the Canal on the 4th inst, 3 of which were British, 2 German, 1 Italian, 1 Dutch, 1 Rus ian, 1 Tarkish.Theday's receipts ware frs. 207,840.93, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 1,365,203.43.

BRITISH RECREATION CLUB.-We understand that yesterday the Government gave the Cairo British Recreation Club written notice to hand back their ground within six months. The Government was only bound to give two months' notice.
ARMY OF OCCUPATION.-After all the talk and commotion about the reduction of the Army of Occupation in Egypt, it may surprise our readers to learn that the total reduction
up to date amounts to about three hundred officers and men.

MIXED APPEAL COURT.-The case of the heirs of the late Advocate Rossetti v. Omar Bey Sultan and Mr. N. Sciplini will be heard on the 12th inst, before the Mixed Appeal Court. Maitre Carton de Wiart will appear for the heirs and Maitres Lusena and Fornario for the defendants.

E.T.C. RATES-This morning, the negotia tions between Sir John Denison Pender and the Egyptian Government in regard to the reduction of the cable rates to England were resumed. Sir John paid a brief visit to Alexaudria yesterday, returning to Cairo in the evening.

FAYOUM LIGHT RAILWAY. The local tribunal of Medinet el-Fayoum has sentenced a station master of the Fayoum Light Railway- Company to four months' imprisonment for stealing goods from merchants who had sent merchandise to the station. The case brought by Mr. Davison against the company has been postponed.

CHARITY FETE.-The annual charity fête in aid of the Conference de Saint Vincent de Paul (house-to-house visitation of the poor) will take place to-morrow at 6.30 p.m. at the Jesuit Chapel. The sermon will be preached by the Rev. Father Louis Poerroy, S.J., and the collection will be made by Mmes. Pierre Girard and Ernest Eeman.

SAYED EL-SADAT'S HOUSEHOLD.-The recent developments in the family affairs of Sayed el- Sadat have caused a great deal of talk in native circles in Cairo. Not only Sofia Hanem, whose marriage with Sheikh Aly Youssef was an nounced last year, and her mother, but another wife of El-Sadat and her daughter have taken refuge at the house of the Princess Nazli Hanem.

SUMMER LEAVE.-Those who are contemplating a journey home this summer should not fail to note the advantageous terms offered to residents by the Orient-Pacific Line. Between May and October the following reduced fares will be in force:-First class, Port Said to Tilbury, £16. 16.0; Port Said to Marseilles, £12. 12.0. Second-class, Port Said to Tilbury. £12. 12. 0; Port Said to Marseilles, £9. 9. 0. These reduced fares are also subject to the usual rebate for passengers returning on the
libe.

GARRISON CHURCH OF ST. GEORGE, MUSTA- PHA PASHA.-The Right Rev. Bishop Morley, D.D., Archdeacon of the Church of England in Egypt, will preach at the parade service at 11 am. on Sunday next, 9th inst., and after the service will administer the rite of Confir mation. There will be a full choral service, and the string band of the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regiment, supplemented by the organ. The collection will be given to the New Organ Fund. Visitors will be cordially welcomed. There will be evensong and sermon at 6.30 p.m., when "The Story of the Cross" will be
sung.

div.head: IS THE ASSOUAN DAM SAFE ?
div.p: A PLEA FOR OBSERVATION AND DELAY.
THE NILE DAM AND ITS TASK.

The question of raising the Nile dam at Assouan is keenly exercising the professional mind. Engineers, more especially those who have had experience of large water schemes, are divided as to whether or not the present barrage ought to be taxed with extra work, and it is reassuring to find a voice raised here and there on the side of prudence and delay. We have interviewed Mr. Ewing Matheson, a wellknown member of the Institute of Civil Engineers, and while expressing confidence in the united experience of the chief experts in this branch. of the profession-men like Messrs. Mansergh, Hawksley, and Bateman-he said Sir Benjamin Baker would be well advised to lengthen the period of observations before the present structure of the dam was added to in any way.

"The Nile dam," said Mr. Matheson to our representative, "was no doubt designed for its present height of water, with a margin of safety, and to raise it to a considerable height means reviving the old question of flooding the island of Phila over again, and matters of public safety that are much more important. It is impossible to foretell or conceive the damage which would be done if the dam were overtaxed."

Mr. Matheson cited the disastrous floods at Sheffield and Johnstown, Pennsylvania, as instances of insufficient planning. "I visited Johnstown," he said, "twelve months after the catastrophe, and saw traces even then of that terrible flood. Fifteen miles away from the scene of the burst, there were locomotives swept aside and overturned, and it was all due to insufficient calculation, added to the usual light-heartedness of the Americans in their constructive undertakings.

div.head: THE FACTORS OF DESTRUCTION.
div.p: The two main considerations in the proper working of a dam of this kind are the rush of water and the height-the 'height' being a teclinical expression for the hydrostatic pressure. It is the rush of water which creates what we call the scour, or attrition along the conduits or subterranean passages; and it was with a view to preserve them that, in the Assouan case, they were paved for a certain portion. Sir Benjamin Baker's recent visit was to report on the working out of these calculations, and as a result this pavement is to be extended. But it will be a matter for the most anxious consideration before the dam is raised, as projected, merely to increase the area of irrigation purposes. Far better wait another year or two, and estimate wear and tear upon the present construction."

"Are there any precedents!" we asked. "Yes, of one kind or another," was the reply, "and the experience in this class of work among British engineers all over the world, as well as in work under British supervision, fortifies us against any novel theories or experiments. There have been just sufficient failures to bring them up to the mark, and in the construction of nasonry dams no possible precaution is now neglected, even where, as in the case of the present construction at Leeds, the volume of water is not to be compared with that of the Nile.

THE OVERWHELMING RISKS. "Everything, depends upon the margin of safety as allowed originally. It must have entered into the minds of the designers that the dam might be raised or thickened later on; and it remained then to see that the dovetailing of the rock foundations were sufficient for any increase in superincumbent weight. Personally, I should advise waiting for another year or two, as I have said, botore considering additions involving perhaps 6lbs. extra pressure to the square inch of surface. The advantages to be gained are dwarfed into insignificance compared with the awful extent of the danger incurred."-"Pall Mall Gazette.")

div.head: THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY.
div.p: The following were the suggestions addressed
to the Government by the members of the General Assembly :-
1. For the creation of a Municipality at Cairo, by Sheikh el Demerdashi.
2. For the construction of a .railroad from Nag Hamadi to Edfou, the conversion of the Ramadi Canal to a Sefi canal, and the construction of an agricultural road from Abou Shousha to Esueh.
3. For the reform of teaching in the kuttabs.
4. For the construction of drains in Cairo and the modification of Article 18 in the statutes referring to the General Assembly, by Sheikh Aly Youssef.
6. For the reform of irrigation in Upper Egypt, by Selem Bey Mashkour, Seir el Nasr Bey Tantawi, Koraiem Bey Koraghi, and Diab Bey Abou Selim.
7. Establishment of a "Kantara" in the Damietta mouth of the Nile instead of building up a sudd every year.
A. S. C.
The race course will be open for galloping to-morrow morning from 6 to 9 o'clock.

div.head: GREEK INDEPENDENCE DAY.-
div.p: At 10 o'clock this morning a Te Deum Mass was celebrated at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral, Alexandria. Mr. Scotidis and the personnel of the Hellenic Consulate were present in full uniform and the President of the Community, Mr. Benachi. The leading members of the Hellenic colony were present, including Mr. Em. M. Sinadino, Salvago, Zervudacbi, Dr. Valassopoulo, etc. The ceremony ended with an appropriate sermon by the Patriarch Photios. The band of the Philharmonic Society played outside and then marched to the Consulate, where a reception was held

div.head: LATE ARCHBISHOP BONFIGLI
div.p: INAUGURATION OF MONUMENT

The tolling of the funeral bell at St. Catherine's Cathedral last night announced that already a year had elapsed since the death of Archbishop Gaudenzio Bonfigli. This morning, a special service was held at the Cathedral, Pietro Magri's requiem mass being sung by the brothers of the Christian Schools, Archbishop Briante officiating. All the clerical orders of the city were represented, and grouped near the high altar were H. E. the Governor, several of the consuls, headed by the French Consul, etc.

The service was of the most impressive character, and the large congregation, it could be seen, was deeply affected. The splendid Miseremini mei especially was rendered with supreme pathos. At the close of the requiem, the celebrant, attended by his clergy, left the altar preceded by the crucifix and acolytes, and went towards the catafalque for the absolution, the time the Christian Brothers sang Libera me.

This ceremony over the Archbishop went to St. Mark's chapel, where the mortal remains of the late Archbishop Bonfigli are laid, and where a monument to his memory has been erected. Mr. Moriondo, president of the memorial committee, here address" ed the Archbishop in Italian, handing over the memorial to his lordship's care. Archbishop Briante replied, thanking the committee for their beautiful gift to the church, which would always receive the most tender and reverent
care.

The parchment containing a record of the ceremony and the names of the clergy connected with the church, was then signed by the consuls present and read by the Pro-Vicar General Amadio Amato, to whose initiative and untiring efforts the erection of the monument is mainly due, and who deserves the thanks of the Catholic community.
The members of the St. Catherine's Club kept order during the service admirably...

div.head: THE DUKE OF THE ABRUZZI.
div.p: H.R.H. the Duke of the Abruzzi left for Cairo yesterday in company with the Marquis di Salvago-Raggi and arrived there at 7.25 p.m. The distinguished visitor at once proceeded to the Savoy Hotel. His Royal Highness is expected to return to Alexandria either tomorrow afternoon or Sunday morning.
The Italian colony will give a ball at the New Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria, on Sunday next in honor of the Dake of the Abruzzi. The officers of the "Liguria" and the Prince's staff will attend.

div.head: THE THEATRE FIRE.
div.p: The fire which caused the destruction of the Abbas Helmy Theatre is generally believed to have been due to the same cause as the other recent great conflagration in the Old Bourse Palace, namely, the fusing of an electric wire. The scene of the fire still attracts large numbers of spectators, but no idea can be obtained of the ruin brought by the fire from an external inspection, as the walls of the building are intact. It is only on entering what was the auditorium that one is able to grasp the extent of the devastating work of the flames. The theatre is absolutely burnt out except the walls. The force of the fire is evidenced by the state of the iron pillars which used to support the boxes. They are nearly all cracked by the fierceness of the heat.

The only thing left untouched by the fire and unspoilt by the water was a large portraitof the actress Bellincioni in the entrance hall. In every other respect the theatre is an abomination of desolation."

div.head: THE COLLAPSE IN THE ATTARIN
div.p: The collapse of a house in the Attarin quarter of Alexandria on Wednesday was not, luckily, attended with any loss of life. The collapse was due to a neighbour excavating by the side of the house in order to make the foundations of a new building. This man texcavated to a depth of at least two and a half metres underneath the foundations of the house. The result was that the house collapsed entirely and two persons were buried in the ruins. One of them was buried under some metres of rubbish and stones and it was ten. minutes before the Fire Brigade managed to get down to him. They bared his head and gave him first-aid, feeding him on whisky and caffeine. It took another full hour to liberate his body, which was severely braised.

A somewhat humorous incident took place when the Fire Brigade had cleared away the earth from the man's head. He was a native Moslem and refused to take the caffeine (Shorbah Ahmar) but asked "Mafish Whisky 1" The Superintendent of the Fire Brigade at once sent a shawish of the police to buy a tumbler of whisky and the contents were poured down the man's mouth, greatly to his relish. He only remarked, "All right, work away," for his arms and entire body were still pinned by the earth. Soon afterwards he was again offered caffeine but refused it, and asked for more whisky, and by the time his body had been extricated, which operation had taken an hour and a quarter, he had consumed a full bottle of whisky. When the stretcher on which he lay was being raised to take him to the bospital he asked whether he could have any more!

div.head: EGYPTIAN MARKETS.
div.p: REPORT FOR THE YEAR.

The directors of the company in their report for the year ended 31st December, 1904 state that for the whole of the year all the markets have, by order of the Government, been closed to horned cattle in consequence of the cattle plague. The gross receipts of the company for the year were:-trom cattle marketa, £16,104; general markets £9,138; abattoirs, £923, total, £26,165, which, together with sundry receipts, makes a grand total of £26,602. This gives an average per market per week of £214s. 7d. for cattle markets (including abattoirs), and of £1 9s. 3d. for general markets. Total £4 38. 10d. Consi derable further economies have been effected during the year in the working of the marketa. the total cost of which has been reduced to £16,035, or £4,537 less than in 1903. In consideration of the heavy losses sustained by the company by the closing of the cattle markets, the directors have agreed to forego their fees for the year under review to the extent of £1,525. The trustees for the debenture holders, the Hon. Alfred Lyttelton and Arthur Wagg, Esq., have also agreed to forego their fees to a corresponding extent.

The directors are gratified to report that the Egyptian Government was in 1904 pleased to grant a ten years' extension of the concession, as some compensation for the losses sustained by the company in consequence of the closing of the markets. In consequence of the extension of the Government concession, a revision of the sinking fand for the redemption of the share capital has been effected, which in fature years will result in a saving to the company of £1,193 per annum, with effect from the 17th Novem ber, 1904. Under the old arrangement the interest per annum upon the debentures of the company and the share capital sinking fund premium combined amounted to £7,444. Under the revised arrangement they will amount to £6,251, effecting a saving per annum of £1,193. After meeting charges for administration and working, the net revenue for the year from all sources amounts to £10,567 0s. 6d. which, together with the balance of £8,015 4s. 11d. brought forward from 1903, makes a total of £18,582 58. 5d. to be dealt with. After payment of the annual premium for the amortisation of share and debenture capital, £5,028 28. 7d., and debenture interest, £4,459 11s. 8d., a balance of £9,094 118. 2d. remains for disposal. Having given the matter their most careful consideration, the directors have decided, in view of the fact that the best season of 1905 has already been lost, not to recommend the payment of a dividend until the re-opening of the cattle markets has been authorised by the Government. The abattoirs continue to show satisfactory and progressive results. The company's share of the net earnings from this source amounted to £922 12s. 5d. The total number now opened is fifteen and Government proposes to build others during 1905, of which five are under construction.

As in the previous year, the directors and staff have done everything in their power to assist the efforts of Government during the year 1904 to entirely eradicate the cattle plague from Egypt. The recognition by Govern- ment, in the extension of the concession, of the losses sustained by the conpany, is fully appreciated, but the directors, in view of the length of time the markets have been closed, still hope that further considerations will be granted. The directors wish to draw the attention of the proprietors to the fact that, notwithstanding the serious losses incurred by the closing of the markets, it has been possible, by the utmost economy and by abandoning their fees and those of the trustees, to meet all working and other expenses. A good deal has been done in the way of negotiations towards sub-letting the markets, but it is not considered opportune to press the conclusion of contracts until the cattle markets are reopened. The directors report the resignation of Lieut.-Col. E.L. Marryat, R.E, from the Board. Major W.I. Le Breton has been elected in his place In accordance with the articles of association, two directors of the company, Major W.I. Le Breton and Mr. W. O. Joseph, retire at this meeting and, being eligible, offer themselves for re-election..

div.head: THE SUCRERIES COMPANY.
div.p: In our issue of the 4th inst., we stated that the Sucreries Company had decided to pay a dividend of 13% for the year 1903-4, i.e., 5% already paid as interim dividend and 8% after the general meeting of 12th inst. Our Cairo Correspondent writes to rectify this information. It appears from his interview with one of the directors of the company that the board intends to propose to the next general meeting a dividend of 8%, of which 5% was paid on October 81 last. The balance to be distributed on April 30 will thus be 3%, if, as is likely, the shareholders adopt the proposition of their board.
It is to be noted that the financial year 1903-

4 was closed before the present rise in the price of sugar, and that it had to defray the exceptional expenditure arising from the taking over by this company of the old Daïra sugar factories. The current year will therefore reap' the profit from the rise in sugar and the increase in the production consequent on the purchase of the Daïra factories.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. "Congo" arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria on Wednesday morning.
The Moss liner "Menes" sailed yesterday afternoon for Liverpool, via Malta, with pas sengers, mails, and general cargo, including 2,782 bales cotton,

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Princess Nazli Hanem and Prince Kámil Pasha left Alexandria yesterday by the Florio- Rubattino S.S. "Tebe."
Herr von Mohl, German Commissioner of the Public Debt, has left Cairo for Luxor accompanied by Miss von Mohl and Mr. Waldemar von Mohl.
The marriage of Mahmoud Bey, son of Mahmoud Pasha Soleiman, with the daughter of Idris Bey Ragheb will be celebrated in Cairo shortly.

A banquet is to be given at Shepheard's Hotel this evening by the counsellors of the Native Court of Appeal in honor of Mr. Coghlan, their ex-colleague, on the occasion of his appointment as judge of the Mixed Courts at Cairo.
Major L'Estrange Johnstone will leave on the 16th inst. for England.

Sir Benjamin Baker, who was sixty-five years of age last week, once planned, long before the recent agitation, an alternative canal to the Suez, inspired thereto by the Khedive Ismail, who desired to restore to Alexandria some of its former prosperity, and asked the great engineer to plan a canal from this port to Cairo, and thence to the Red Sea. Sir Benja min did so, found it would cost ten millions or more, and Ismail abandoned his dream.
Dr. and Mrs. F. W. Saunders have arrived at the Ghezireh Palace Hotel from Luxor.
Mr. W. Wilfred Carey, assistant commis sioner of the State Domains Administration, and Mrs. Carey are leaving to-day for England.

Rev. W. Dickins, A.W.C.P., is leaving by the 8. 8. "Niger" to-day for Europe on six months' leave of absence and will be replaced as officiating Wesleyan chaplain to the Forces by the Rev. W. Float, Ibrahimieh.
The Khedive has conferred the rank of Mirmiran on Hussein Bey Chahin and Seifullab Bey.

div.head: DOGS IN TRAINS.
div.p: A Zeitoun correspondent writer:- May I be allowed through the medium of your columns to draw the attention of the Railway authorities to a state of affairs which has been, and still is, an intolerable nuisance as well as a sanitary danger, viz., the presence of dogs in the first-class carriages on the Pont Limoun-Marg railway,-dogs, moreover, not merely lying on the floor, but reposing on the seats. Even a clean and healthy dog is objec tionable in a railway carriage; how much more so are dogs, dirty, mangy, and densely popula ted, such as are constantly seen on the line in question?

In any civilised country this would not be allowed, as there, the health and comfort of the passengers are the first consideration of the Railway authorities, which does not seem to be the case on this particular branch of the Egyptian State Railways. I feel sure, however, that this matter has only to be brought to the notice of the responsible Railway officials for them to take the necessary steps to put a stop to this reprehensible practice.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie)
D'importantes réalisations ont occasionné une baisse générale qui pourra s'accentuer encore un peu mais qui fera bientôt place à une reprise.

La Banque Nationale tombe de 27 7/8 à 27 5/8, le Crédit Foncier de 345 à 339, l'Agricole de 13 25/32 à 13 1/2, la Daira de 27 13/16 à 27 7/16, l'Anglo American Nile de 6 1/4 à 6 1/16 et la Delta Light de 14 1/2 à 14 1/4. On est vendeurs aux nouvaux cours.
Les petites valeurs suivent le même mouvement: l'Investment fléchit à 2 1/4, les Estates. à 1 7/32, la Filature à 27/32 et les Cotton Mills à 5/3.
Par contre la Delta Land hausse de 3 9/16 à 3 13/16 et les Eaux du Caire de 1250 à 1260.

Mtre Martino a protestd vivemdht contre cfl ; systime de defense; il est inadmissible que les / Suoreries essayent de justifier le'renvoi d'un c employd en lprbdtuunt au dossier des pidcos f dont elles reconnaissent si bien le caraotdre 1 diffamatoTro que lour avocat nose les lire à l'audiende. Par le fait de la mise au dossier, la1 piice a re$u une publioitd suffisante aux tenues de la loi pour justifier la demande de dommages-intdrdta.

div.head: Mesopotamia
div.p: The Tigris enters its delta at Baled, near thesite of the ancient Opis, where were situated the famous weirs of antiquity and which were 'described by Tavernier. I used to think that these weirs were altogether artificial, bnt an examination of the site has made me think that they were natural bars of .vory hard conglomerate, as hard as. the compactest crys- talline limestone, which overlay stiff clay. The crests of the weirs wore probably artifi- cially raised. This conglomerate can bo seen to-day.along the left bank of the river from Samarra to nearly opposite Boled. It has a thickness of over ip metres at Samarra, and under it can be seen some 6 metres of stiff ~*any above the water's edge of the Tigris. The conglomerate dips under the allurvum of the Tigris below Beled and its termination was in Probability a great cataract near Beled known .ally as "Sadd Nimrud," or Nimrod's dam. 'file Nahrwan and Dijail canals look out from above these weire^ .The Nahrwan canal was ruined by the Tigris changing its course, and the undermining and sweeping away of these great cataracts sealed the ruin of all the irrigation systems fed by the Tigris. From Beled to Bagdad the Tigris has a length of about 110 kilometres, and a width of from 4 kilometres to 350 'metres. Where the river is wide, it flows over a bed of shingle and has a velocity pf some 6 to 7 kilometres per hour. Navigation by sailing boats is impossible against the current.

From Bagdad to Gurnn,whore tho Tigris and Euphrates meet, the river has a length of 740 kilometres. The distance from Gnrna to Basra is 60 kilometres, and 100 kilometres further on is the Persian Gulf. Tho distances along the Tigris are therefore as follows . . ' From Beled to tho Sea J 1010 kilometres From Bagdad to Basra 800 „ From Bagdad to the Sea 900 „ After.leaving the rapids at Beled, the bed of tftj Tigris, like that of the Euphrates, is'every- where mud. The watere are yellow like those of the Tiber and the Euphrates. Bagdad is the real northern terminus of river navigation on the Tigris. It has taken, the place of the ancient Opis, which was further north

The following tables of very approximative mean heights of the Tigris at Bagdad will give a fair.idea of times for flood and low supply:— January February March - .April • May June July „ . August September October November December 2.00 3.00 '6.00^ ff.00 5.50 3.50 2.00 1.00 ' 0.00, 0.00 1.50 1.00 1000 1600 3000 4000 3500 1500 1000 1500 o. metres per second.

div.head: A QUEER GRAMMAR.
div.p: To rta Editor of the Egyptian Gazette. Sir,—In reply to "Grammarian's" lette.r in yesterday's "Gazette," I hive to inform him:— .(1) Not long before reviewing Dirr's Arabic Grammar, the "Gazette" published my opinion of another grammar of the classical language, which was most flattering and which was afterwards shared by the editor of a well-known literary Arabic periodical inJJairo in his review of it (2) ' Before sending in mf artiole on Dirr's grammar I gave the book to a native friend (who is a competent Arabio scholar) to read and return to me with his opinion. He brought it after a few days and told me what he thought of it in fewer but severer words than I used. I then gave him my article to read and he approved of every word I said. Moreover, I have not yet met one who knew the book and did not share my opinion of it (3) Since sending my article to the "Gazette" 1 have learned that the book had been sent to an Euglish gentleman who is a well- known Arabic scholar, but although he refused to review it he marked here and there what he considered flagrant errors. The reason of his refusal is therefore not far to seek. . (4) I confirm every word I said in my review, but I cannot enter into any discussion with one who makes the ridioulous statement that it is grammatically correct to say el ingi- lyz tayiba because he means the English as a nation, and pretends that most of the other mistakes are obvious slips. (5) "Grammariau" has the fault of more than one other resident in the country who no sooner- picks up? a few words of Arabio (and before he could write a sentence correctly without the aid of some one else) than be rushes.to the press with a wonderful grammar of his own. It would have been better for "Grammarian" to study the language for many more years before venturing to write a book dealing with it (6) "Grammarian'' will have to get all the , mistakes I pointed out, and many more, cor- ; need before the book ceases to be called a . "queer'' grammar.. As regards his personal reference to me, there is no need for me to reply, as this sort of controversial method is beneath contempt.— Yours very truly,

div.head: SUDAN EXPLORATION SHARES
div.p: Mr. Justice Kekewich in the Chancery Divi- sion on,Tahsday w§ek continued the hearing of the notion in which'Dr. Robert William Eelkin Rued the Palmerston Industrial and Finance Corporation, Ltd., and Mr. Alfred -Bridge, a company promoter, of-15, Cockspur-street, W., claiming rescission of an agreement to take 800 shares in the Sudan Exploration, Ltd., and a declaration that defendants were liable to indemnify the plaintiff in respect of all expen- ses incurred by him in relation to the transac- tion, or in the alternative damages for alleged misrepresentation. The corporation denied that its policy or business was controlled by Bridge, and did not admit that the representations alleged to have been made by him were made on behalf of the corporation or with its know- ledge. The.defendant Bridge pleaded that if he did. make any representations or statements concerning the present or future value of the shares they were bona fide expressions of opi- nion. Defendant Bridge counter-claimed againit the plaintiff for alleged misrepresentation.— Mr. P. Ogden Lawrence, K. C. and Mr. J; H. Simmons appeared for plaintiff, Mr. Ashton Cross for the Palmerston Corporation, and Mr. W. J. L Ambrose for Mr. Bridge. Plaintiff, continuing his evidence, said that up to the issue of the writ in this action he had never received a certificate for or transfer of the 800 shares in the . Sudan Exploration, Ltd.

In cross-examination by Mr. Ashton Cross, for the Palmerston Corporation, plaintiff said he knew the property which the Siidan Explo- ration had been formed to acquire. From his knowledge of the country witness believed the company's property to be valuable. Ho wa3 anxious to g|t some Sudan sbures if he could pay cash for them. The 10$. nominal shares could not be obtained for less than £1. Ho Btill believed in tho success of the Sudan Company if it was well managed. Mr. Ashton Cross said he agreed that the Palmerston Corporation sold the shares to Dr. Felkip and those shares had been delivered. Plaintiff, >n auswer to counsel, said ho be- lieved that the 800 shares were in the Sudan Company's hands' for transfer. In cross-examination by ' Mr. Ambrose, plaintiff said he understood that the Palmerston Corporation was to put the shares on the mar- ket at-£2 when the pooling-arrangement came to an end. He always understood that Bridge was actiug for the Palmerston Corporation. This concluded plaintiff's case, and Mr. Ashton Cross, submitting that ho case had been made out against the corporation, called Mr. Allred Bridge, who described himself as a director of. the Palmerston Corporation, of which,he said,tho plaintiff also beoamo a direc- tor. When the question of the Sudan Explora- tion shares was uuder discussion, plaintiff said that if he went into the matter ho should want a share of the profits, and witness then told him he had better become a director. Plaintiff, said witness, worked hand-in-hand with him in the Sudan matter, and advised the corporation to take up the shares. Witness denied that he ever made any representations to induce plaintiff to go into the share transaction, and he said that Dr. Felkin must have understood the whole transaction.

Cross-examined by Mr. Lawrence, witness said that he was a company promoter, and prior to his going to Cockspur-street he carried on business at 8, Union-court, FC., where he promoted a number of companies. May I take it that, all the companies you promoted come to grief?—No.—Witness men- tioned the Pan-African Syndicate, Ltd., and the London and Provincial Dairy Company as suocossful promotions. Witness denied that at the time he left'Union-courtoxocutions were out against him at his office and at his house at Surbiton. Wore there any baukruptcy petitions presented against you ?—Yes. May I tako it that altogether 8, Union-court, got too hot for yon at tho time you migrated to the West End ?—No, not at all.—Witness said he sometimes advertised for directors willing to invest It was not true to suggest that witness was the Palmerston Corporation. He agreed that there was no entry in the mi- nute-books concerning the agreement with tho plaintiff. At the date of the signing of the bill by the plaintiff witness admitted that the only transfer of Sudan shares to the Palmer ston Corporation was one for 600 shqres. They had, however,' made arrangements to acquirejurther shares.

The abovo teams met at Abbassieh xm Wednesday last. Both teams hold a good record. The K.R.R's, it seems, have not been defeated since 1902, whereas the representatives of the Shamrook have only been beaten onoe in some sixtyodd matches,60 a good game was expected. The pitch was in splendid order as the Irishmen took the field in the following order : Goal, Dadgeon ; backs, Shanks and Reid ; halves, Millar, Nixon, and Smyth ; forwards, Todd, Hutton, Cunningham, Fallon, and Walsh. The Rifles won the spin of the coin and defended the city goals. There would be almost 900 spectators present when Cunningham commenced operations.. The opening minutes proved sensational as the Inuiskillings bom- barded the Rifles' goal for fully five minutes. The custodian clearing the Rifles now broke away per Bibbleton, but Smyth robbed and returned. Todd getting possession centred well but Fallon sent behind. On the kick-off tho Rifles took play towards Dudgeon, but the latler was not to be oanght napping and cleared in Gillispie's best style. At this stage the referee (a sergeant of the K.KR.'s) had occasion to retire owing to a misunderstanding of the roles, Mr. MoKenzie, Royal Engineers, filling the vacanoy (amid cheers). On play being resumed Cunningham got away and sent across to Todd, who outwitted two opponents and seut strongly into goal, where Fallon headed over the bar. Flay remained in midfield, until Fallon broke away, but when in a good position ho was! fouled by Bibbleton. A fight ensued, both players being oantioned. The Rifles' right wiug now got away but Smyth intercepted and returned. Some very spirited play 'took place around the Rifles' goal. At last, however, the custodian cleared. The Irishmen were now ' having the best of matters and a shot of Cunningham's deserved a better fate. A free against the Green and Buff Brigade proved unproductive. It was close on half-timo as Hutton gave the Dark Greens' defence some trouble. Half-time now arrived with the repre- seratives of the Shamrock pressing for all they were worth,but there was no score yet on either side.

After the usual refreshments both teams took tho field. The first thing noticeable was a great sprint by Todd. The ball, however, found touch. The Rifles now took play in hand, but Smith robbed the right wing -time after time. A corner to the Rifles looked ridrie too rosy for the Green and Buff Brigade, HoWeker Nixon cleared and the InniskUliugs were seen fio advantage. Walsh, however, ran the ball ovet tho liue. On the kick off Bibbleton got away, on his own, but Smith was on his track aneb blocked his passage once more. Not to be deniod, the Rifles got down towards Dudgeon and scored, but Johnny Bibbleton was given offside. On resuming, Millar got away on his own, and alter dodging a couple of opponents sent across to Cunningham, who had a good try for goal. The Rifles now pulled themselves togother and worked their way down towards Dudgeon but Nixon and Smith were not to be beaten so easily and play was once more trans- ferred, when Hutton got well away and gave to Todd, who aont in a "daisy cutter" to tho Custodian, who fell on the ball but too late, as Fallou gut the ball at his toe and into the net it went, drawing first blood for the Innis- killings amidst deafening cheers. Oa the ball being centred the K.RR's got away but' Reid returned the ball. Great was the excitement that now prevailed (at this stage Mion was injured and had to retire). Both teams were now playing a most determined and very hard game. If anything, the Inniskillingswere having tho best of matters at this stage. The shield holders were playing a fine combination game. It was a treat to watoh the five forwards play so woll considering tho circumstances under which they were placod. It was now wearing up to full'time as Walsh missed the much desired spot by inches. Shortlyafterthereferee's whistle sounded for full time, leaving the Inniskillings winners of one of the most exciting games that ever took place in Cairo, and still undefeated. Final result 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers*-! Goal. 1st King's Royal Rifles—Nil

div.p: La Mnnicipalito d'Alexandrie ddsirerait pour sea bureaux, un noinbro de nouveaux stagiaires ne ddpassant pas quatro pour, le moment Les conditions requises \sont la connaissanco Scribe et parlte des langobs framjaiso et arabe, un certificat de bonne eondnite et one santo nor- male. Les stagiaires serviront pendant six mois au maximum sans traitoment et recevront ensuite s'ils ont donn6 satisfaction trois livres par mois jnsqu'h oe qu'un poste dans les cadres vienne h devenir vacant Les demande8 pour cea postes seront admisea jusqu'au -12 Avril 1906. Un avis nltdrieur indiquera le jour et l'heure oh le coneoure aura lien it la Municipality parmi les postulants dont les demandes auront eto aoceptoes.

Les off res dovront fitre adressdos sous pli caoheto A Monsieur l'Administratour do la Municipalito avant le 11 conrant Elies pourront dgalement fitro ddposdes en stance de laDyldgation le mSme jour A 5h.p.m. L'enveloppe devra fin outre porter la men- tion r "Soomission pour fonrnitnre de Chakf." Le cautionnement ou le re^u d'une banque d'aprfis les conditions du cahier des charges, devra fit re remis sdparfiment au Service de la Comptabilitfi Gfinfirale avant 1'oaverture des offres et an plus tard le 11 courant A midi.
